message: The Mac App Store has been official since the beginning of the year, and there's thousands upon thousands of apps in many categories. A lot of apps are very appealing, and apps that I used to enjoy prior to it's release are starting to become counter-productive.  I'd like to experience some of the newer apps that are available, but you can't go without paying for them.  Short of technical issues with the app I've never been able to receive a refund because the app was not fitting to my needs.  TL;DR version: Why don't trial periods exist in the Mac App Store?
technically the mac app store is kinda in beta, i think a better a version will be release along side 10.7 this summer
I try to use developer's sites. Plus there are still great free Mac apps that don't aren't on the store.
Most apps at the Mac App Store have demos/trials available at the dev’s site. So do try them. The Mac App Store isn’t the only way to get apps.
I know that there's a rule for app validation on iOS at least that says they won't allow apps that are beta, demo or trial. Maybe that's the same on the Mac.
Lite versions are available, eg. Sparrow
if they allow lite versions is the lite just the politically correct term for demo/beta these days.
@MarkLaViolette, no. Demo — usually pre-release, not all features, but no bugs. Beta — with bugs. Lite — released, but w/ limited functionality and often ad-supported.
